instruction: Create a one-sentence summary of a paper using the provided information to capture its main idea succinctly.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the main idea and condense it into one sentence.

instruction: Reword the paragraph without altering or omitting any information, but feel free to modify sentence structure or vocabulary.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Use synonyms and alter sentence structure while maintaining original meaning.

instruction: Summarize the given text in no more than three sentences, capturing the main points and key details.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the main points and condense them into three sentences.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and after years of climbing the academic ladder, they figured one more climb couldn't hurt! so there they were, perched at the top, trying to reach for that elusive drink. the bartender looks up and says, "you know, you could just ask me for a drink." the phd student replies, "i thought i'd have to submit a proposal first!" they both laugh, but then the bartender adds, "well, if you're going to be up there, can you change the light bulb?" and so began another chapter in the life of a multitasking scholar!
output_type: Identify the punchline and humor elements.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and after years of climbing the academic ladder, they thought it was finally time for some elevation! so there they were, standing in line with their trusty ladder, ready to reach new heights. the bartender noticed them and asked, "why the ladder?" the student replied, "well, i figured since i've been reaching for unattainable goals all these years, why not keep the tradition alive?" the bartender chuckled and said, "you know, you could just ask for help." the student paused, looked at the ladder, then back at the bartender, and said, "asking for help... now that's an idea worth defending!" and so, they both laughed, realizing that sometimes the best way to elevate yourself is by asking others to lend a hand.
output_type: None

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the library? because they heard their research was going to take them to new heights, and they wanted to be prepared! so there they were, climbing up each rung of the academic ladder: coursework, comprehensive exams, dissertation proposal... each step felt like an eternity. finally, they reached the top with their completed dissertation in hand. as they stood triumphantly on the highest shelf, they realized something profound—there was another ladder labeled "postdoc" right next to it!
output_type: Identify the humor and metaphor in the narrative.

instruction: Quick pre-run warmup routine: - arm circles: stand with feet shoulder-width apart, extend arms to the sides and make small circles forward for 30 seconds, then backward. - leg swings: hold onto a wall or support, swing one leg forward and backward for 15 reps, then switch legs. - hip circles: place hands on hips, rotate hips in a circular motion clockwise for 10 reps, then counterclockwise. - walking lunges: step forward into a lunge position, alternate legs as you walk across a space for about 10 lunges per leg. - high knees: jog in place while lifting knees high towards your chest for 30 seconds.
output_type: None

instruction: Quick pre-run warmup routine: - high knees: stand in place and jog by lifting your knees high towards your chest to activate the hip flexors. - leg swings: hold onto a wall for balance, swing one leg forward and backward to loosen up the hips. - arm circles: extend arms out to the sides and make small circles to warm up the shoulders. - lunges with a twist: step forward into a lunge, then twist your torso towards the front leg to engage the core. - ankle bounces: lightly bounce on your toes to prepare the calves and ankles.

instruction: Create a summary of the paragraph while maintaining all original information but altering sentence structure and vocabulary.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Rephrase sentences while preserving the original meaning. Use synonyms to alter vocabulary.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the library? because they heard that knowledge is something you have to reach for, and they wanted to get ahead in their research! so there they were, climbing up the rungs of academia, hoping to finally grasp those elusive high-level concepts. but as they reached the top shelf, they realized it was just filled with more books on how to write a dissertation. undeterred, they climbed down, only to find themselves surrounded by fellow students who had also brought ladders. they all laughed, realizing that while they might be reaching for the stars, sometimes it's about finding humor in the climb itself.
output_type: Identify the humor and metaphor in the narrative.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and after years of climbing the academic ladder, they thought they'd finally reach new heights! so, there they were, perched atop their trusty ladder, ordering a drink. the bartender, bemused, asked, "why the ladder?" the student replied, "well, i've been climbing for so long in my research, i figured i'd need it to get anywhere!" the bartender chuckled and said, "here’s your drink, but you know, we have stairs too." the student sighed, "stairs are great, but i'm used to taking the longest route possible—just like with my dissertation!"
output_type: Identify the humor elements and structure them coherently.

instruction: Rewrite the paragraph using simpler language suitable for a younger audience.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models have shown they can handle new tasks without being specifically trained for them. However, they rely a lot on human-written instructions, which are often not enough in number, variety, or creativity, limiting the model's general abilities. We introduce Self-Instruct, a way to make these models better at following instructions by using their own generated content. Our process creates instructions, inputs, and outputs from a language model, then removes any that are invalid or too similar before using them to improve the original model. When we applied this to the basic GPT3, we saw a 33% improvement on a specific test, matching the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private data and human help. We also tested with expert-written instructions for new tasks and found that our method outperformed existing public instruction datasets, with only a small gap remaining behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct offers a nearly annotation-free way to align pre-trained language models with instructions, and we are sharing our large synthetic dataset to help future research on instruction tuning.
output_type: Simplify complex terms and concepts. Use shorter sentences and familiar words.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and they wanted to reach new heights in their research! so, this student walks into the bar with the ladder, and everyone stares. the bartender asks, "why the ladder?" the student replies, "i'm working on my thesis about reaching higher levels of understanding." the bartender nods and says, "well, you might want to start by understanding that our roof isn't open for climbing!" undeterred, the student sets up the ladder anyway, climbs to the top, and shouts down, "from up here, i can see all the way to my graduation day!" everyone laughs, except the other phd students who are busy calculating the probability of actually graduating.
output_type: Identify the main punchline and humor elements.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and after years of climbing the academic ladder, they thought it was finally time for some real elevation! so there they were, standing with their trusty old ladder, explaining to everyone how they've been climbing through undergrad, then master's, and now this elusive doctorate. the bartender chuckled and said, "well, at least you know how to handle steps!" to which the phd student replied, "steps are easy; it's the funding that's always out of reach!"
output_type: Identify the humor in the play on words and academic journey.

instruction: Quick pre-run warmup routine: - high knees: stand in place and lift your knees to hip level as quickly as possible for 30 seconds. this increases heart rate and warms up the leg muscles. - leg swings: hold onto a wall or support, swing one leg forward and backward for 15 reps each side. it helps loosen up the hips and hamstrings. - arm circles: extend arms out to the sides and make small circles, gradually increasing to larger ones for 30 seconds. this activates shoulder muscles. - lunges with a twist: step forward into a lunge, twist your torso towards the front leg, then return to standing. do 10 reps per side to engage core and legs. - ankle bounces: stand on toes and bounce lightly for 30 seconds. this prepares the calves and ankles for running impact.
output_type: None

instruction: Identify and list all the entities mentioned in the paragraph.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify and list all proper nouns and specific terms.

instruction: Paraphrase the paragraph while maintaining all information, allowing changes in sentence structure and vocabulary.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Change sentence structure while preserving meaning. Use synonyms to vary vocabulary.

instruction: Paraphrase the paragraph while maintaining all information, but you may change sentence structure or vocabulary.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models, which are finetuned to respond to instructions, have shown an impressive ability to generalize to new tasks without prior examples. However, they rely heavily on human-written instruction data, which is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, thus restricting the model's generality. We present Self-Instruct, a framework to enhance the instruction-following abilities of pretrained language models by leveraging their own generated content. Our process involves generating instructions, inputs, and outputs from a language model, filtering out invalid or redundant ones, and using the remaining data to finetune the original model. By applying this method to the vanilla GPT3, we achieve a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, matching the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further assessment, we compile a set of expert-written instructions for new tasks and demonstrate through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct significantly surpasses using existing public instruction datasets, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct offers an almost annotation-free approach to align pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our extensive synthetic dataset to support future research on instruction tuning.
output_type: Change sentence structure while preserving meaning. Use synonyms to alter vocabulary.

instruction: Summarize the provided text in no more than three sentences.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify key points and condense them into three sentences.

instruction: Summarize the main points of the article provided in 150 words or less.
input: The article discusses the development of a new framework called Self-Instruct, which enhances the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models. This framework generates its own instructions, inputs, and outputs, filtering out invalid or repetitive ones, and uses them to finetune the original model. The method shows a significant improvement in performance, achieving results comparable to models trained with human annotations. Self-Instruct offers a nearly annotation-free approach to align language models with instructions and provides a large synthetic dataset for future research.
output_type: Identify key points and condense them into a concise summary.

instruction: Summarize the main idea of each paragraph in the provided text.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.

instruction: Convert the following paragraph into bullet points for easier reading.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Break down the paragraph into key points and list them as bullet points.

instruction: Summarize the main findings or contributions of the paper in one concise sentence.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the main findings and contributions of the paper.

instruction: Identify and explain three major themes in the given historical event.
input: The French Revolution was a period of radical social and political change in France from 1789 to 1799. It led to the overthrow of the monarchy, the rise of radical political groups, and the establishment of a republic. Key events include the storming of the Bastille, the Reign of Terror, and the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte. The revolution was driven by Enlightenment ideals, economic hardship, and demands for political representation.
output_type: Analyze the impact of Enlightenment ideals on revolutionary thought. Examine the role of economic hardship in fueling unrest. Discuss the shift from monarchy to republicanism and its implications.

instruction: Rewrite the paragraph using more descriptive language.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Use vivid adjectives and adverbs to enhance descriptions. Expand on key concepts with illustrative examples.

instruction: Generate a summary of the provided text
input: The text discusses the development and impact of large "instruction-tuned" language models, which are finetuned to respond to instructions. These models show strong zero-shot generalization to new tasks but rely on limited human-written instruction data. The Self-Instruct framework is introduced to enhance these models by generating and filtering instructions, inputs, and outputs from the models themselves, leading to significant performance improvements. The method is applied to GPT3, achieving a 33% improvement on Super-NaturalInstructions and nearing the performance of InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct offers an annotation-free approach to align language models with instructions, and a large synthetic dataset is released for further research.
output_type: Identify key themes and condense information into a concise summary.

instruction: Paraphrase the paragraph without altering or omitting any information.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Rephrase each sentence while maintaining the original meaning.

instruction: Provide a summary of the given text within 100 words.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify key points and condense them into a concise summary.

instruction: Write a summary of the research paper in 200 words.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify key findings and methods. Condense information to fit word limit.

Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.

instruction: Summarize the significance of their groundbreaking study in one sentence.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the core achievement and its impact on the field.

instruction: Develop a short quiz based on the information provided in the article.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify key concepts and improvements mentioned in the article. Formulate questions that test understanding of these concepts.

instruction: Summarize how quantum computing uses principles of quantum mechanics to process information.
input: Quantum computing leverages principles of quantum mechanics, such as superposition and entanglement, to process information in ways that classical computers cannot. Superposition allows quantum bits (qubits) to exist in multiple states simultaneously, enabling parallel computation. Entanglement provides a way for qubits to be interconnected, allowing for complex problem-solving capabilities and faster information processing.
output_type: Highlight the role of superposition and entanglement in quantum computing.

instruction: Develop a list of potential research questions inspired by the content of the text.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify gaps or limitations in the current research. Explore potential applications or implications of the Self-Instruct framework.

instruction: Rewrite the paragraph using simpler language while maintaining the original meaning.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models have shown they can handle new tasks without specific training. However, they rely on human-written instructions, which are often limited. We introduce Self-Instruct, a method to improve these models by using their own generated data. This process creates and filters instructions and examples to refine the model. Testing on GPT3, we saw a 33% improvement, matching InstructGPT-001, which used private data. We also tested with expert instructions and found Self-Instruct nearly matches InstructGPT-001, with only a 5% difference. Self-Instruct offers a way to align models with instructions without much annotation, and we share our dataset for future research.
output_type: Simplify complex terms and sentences while keeping the core message intact.

instruction: Recommend three books related to the topic discussed in the article.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify books on AI and machine learning advancements. Look for books on language model training and instruction tuning.

instruction: Summarize the main themes of "to kill a mockingbird" by harper lee in 200 words.
input: "To Kill a Mockingbird" by Harper Lee explores themes such as racial injustice, moral growth, and the coexistence of good and evil. The story is set in the racially charged atmosphere of the American South during the 1930s and follows the Finch family, particularly young Scout and her brother Jem, as their father, Atticus Finch, defends a black man, Tom Robinson, falsely accused of raping a white woman. Through their experiences, the children learn about the deep-seated racism in their community and the importance of empathy and understanding. The novel also addresses the loss of innocence and the moral development of the characters as they confront the harsh realities of their society.
output_type: Identify key themes such as racial injustice and moral growth. Summarize how these themes are portrayed through the characters and plot.

instruction: Analyze the provided text and summarize it in three sentences.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.

instruction: Summarize the given text in one sentence.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the core message and condense it into one sentence.

instruction: Propose three potential research questions based on the topic discussed.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify gaps or limitations in the current research. Consider potential applications or implications of the research. Explore comparative analysis with existing methods.

instruction: Develop a multiple-choice question with four options based on the content of the passage.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify key concepts and details from the passage. Formulate a question and plausible options based on these details.

instruction: Why did the phd student bring a ladder to the bar? because they heard the drinks were on the house, and after years of climbing the academic ladder, they figured they'd finally reach new heights! so, there they were, precariously balancing at the top, trying to order a drink while explaining their thesis on quantum mechanics to anyone who would listen. the bartender, amused but slightly concerned, asked, "why don't you just come down here and enjoy your drink?" the student replied, "i've been in academia so long, i forgot how to do anything without overcomplicating it!" and as they wobbled back down, they realized that sometimes, it's okay to take things one step at a time—literally.
output_type: Identify the punchline and humor elements.

instruction: Rewrite the paragraph in passive voice while maintaining its original meaning.
input: Large "instruction-tuned" language models (i.e., finetuned to respond to instructions) have demonstrated a remarkable ability to generalize zero-shot to new tasks. Nevertheless, they depend heavily on human-written instruction data that is often limited in quantity, diversity, and creativity, therefore hindering the generality of the tuned model. We introduce Self-Instruct, a framework for improving the instruction-following capabilities of pretrained language models by bootstrapping off their own generations. Our pipeline generates instructions, input, and output samples from a language model, then filters invalid or similar ones before using them to finetune the original model. Applying our method to the vanilla GPT3, we demonstrate a 33% absolute improvement over the original model on Super-NaturalInstructions, on par with the performance of InstructGPT-001, which was trained with private user data and human annotations. For further evaluation, we curate a set of expert-written instructions for novel tasks, and show through human evaluation that tuning GPT3 with Self-Instruct outperforms using existing public instruction datasets by a large margin, leaving only a 5% absolute gap behind InstructGPT-001. Self-Instruct provides an almost annotation-free method for aligning pre-trained language models with instructions, and we release our large synthetic dataset to facilitate future studies on instruction tuning.
output_type: Identify the verbs and convert them to passive voice. Adjust sentence structure to maintain meaning.
